newsitem.title: GREECE: ATHLETICS-BOLDON AT LAST MATCHES PERFORMANCE TO POTENTIAL.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-BOLDON AT LAST MATCHES PERFORMANCE TO POTENTIAL.

text.p: Ato Boldon, the self-proclaimed future of sprinting, matched performance to potential for the first time at a major championships on Friday by winning the world 200 title.
Boldon, desperately disappointed at finishing fifth in Sunday's 100 final after clocking 9.87 seconds in the second round, won by five metres from Namibia's 1993 champion Frankie Fredericks.
The Trinidadian was unhappy with his time of 20.04 seconds but elated with his victory.
"I wanted to give the people something they would remember," he said. "I want to succeed in sport. I want to be the future of sport."
Wilson Kipketer, an overwhelming favourite to retain the 800 metres title after equalling Seb Coe's 16-year-old world record last month, won as expected although he never threatened the world mark.
"I was pretty certain I was going to get the gold," Kipketer said. "I am fed up talking about the world record. I wanted to win the gold medal and the title."

The biggest surprise of the evening came in the women's 400 metres hurdles, expected to develop into a battle between the Olympic champion Deon Hemmings and the 1995 world champion and world record holder Kim Batten.
Instead Moroccan Nezha Bidouane emerged from the pack in a sizzling final 100 metres to win 13 years to the day after her compatriot Nawal el Moutawakel took the Olympic title in Los Angeles.
"I am the first woman to win a world title for Morocco and I am very proud," said Bidouane.
Ukrainian Zhanna Pintussevich took over from Merlene Ottey as the world 200 champion, as the 37-year-old Jamaican, finally showing her years, faded badly over the final few metres.
"With 20 metres to go I started to realise I could win," said Pintussevich. "And then I thought 'Oh no, this is not possible'," Pintussevich, who also won silver in the 100, said.
The final gold of the sixth day of competition went to Cuban Yoelvis Quesada, who beat both the Olympic and world champions in the men's triple jump.
Quesada set a year's best and Cuban record with a second round leap of 17.85 to join long jumper Ivan Pedroso and high jumper Javier Sotomayor as world champions.
"In Cuba we have a good tradition of jumpers. All the kids want to jump," said Quesada. "Good jumpers are like water in Cuba, plentiful."
Britain's defending champion and world record holder Jonathan Edwards took the silver while American Kenny Harrison, the Olympic champion, finished in ninth place.
